Oct. 19, 1900. To the Adjutant Gener-
al of the Army. Sir: I have the
honor to recommend that Major Wal-
ter Reed, Surgeon U.S.A., Curator,
Army Med. Museum, S.G.O., now in this
city, be detailed as a delegate to
represent the Medical Dept. of the
Army at the meeting of the American
Public Health Association to be
held at Indianapolis, Ind. from Oct.
22 to 26, 1900. Major Reed has an
important communication to make
with reference to his recent re-

Oct. 24, 1900 A. H. Doty, Quar-
antine, Staten Island, N.Y.,
Oct. 23 Telegraphs: Has
Dr. Walter Reed left for
Indianapolis? If so,
will you be kind enough
to wire me his address.
W.E.E.

Oct. 23, 1900. Dr. A. H. Doty, Quarantine
S.I., N.Y. Dr. Walter Reed has left
for Indianapolis. Address care of
Secretary American Public Health As-
sociation.

Oct. 23, 1900. Major Walter Reed,
Care Secretary American Public
Health Association, Indianapolis, Ind.

Gould will publish your paper
in Philadelphia Medical Journal on
Saturday. He requests that you
will not give any extensive ex-
cerpts to the daily papers.
Sternberg, Surgeon General.
B.M.I.

Dec. 10, 1900. Major Walter Reed, Sur-
geon, U.S.A., Havana, Cuba. Sir: I
have to inform you that ten copies
of the “Abstract of Report on the
Origin and Spread of Typhoid fever
in U. S. Military Camps during the
Spanish War of 1898” have been sent
to your address at Havana, Cuba, and
that forty copies of the same re-
port have been left in the hands of
Mr. C. J. Myers at the Army medical
Museum for your disposal.

Dec. 27, 1900. To the Adjutant Gener-
al of the Army. Sir: I have the
honor to recommend that Major Wal-
ter Reed, Surgeon U.S.A., now in Hav-
ana, Cuba, may, in addition to the
Medical Officers named in paragraph
[unclear] S.O., 266, A.G.O., Nov. 12, 1900, be
detailed to represent the Medical
Dept. of the Army at the Pan-Ameri-
can Medical Congress to meet in
the city of Havana, Cuba, Feb. 5, 1901.
G.M.S., S.G., U.S.A:
B.M.I.
